# GUIs and CLIs

## GUI {.nostretch}

Windows and Mac use a Graphical User Interface (GUI) for you to interact with 
the Operating System.

![](images/finder_window.jpg){width=50%}


## About GUIs

- Easy to learn
- Rely on visual displays
- Have improved the friendliness and usability of computers
- Excellent for:
    + Photo editing
    + Document Layout
    + Browsing the web
    + Graphic design
    + Watching movies
    + Playing Games


## GUIs Trade-offs

- They are limiting
- They don't allow you to have more control over what your computer can do
- Some operations are labor intensive and repetitive
- You use clicking & dragging with the cursor/finger, which reduces reproducibility


##

\

### Instead of a GUI, you can use a Command-Line Interface (CLI)

The command line is a text-based interface where you type commands and direct text-based input and output to the screen, to files, or to other programs.


## CLIs

- CLI: Command Line Interface
- The command-line is a text-based interface
- Interacting with the computer via commands
- The user issues commands in the form of text
- One of the earliest ways of interacting with a computer


## {.nostretch}

![](images/terminal-shell.png){width="70%" fig-align="center"}


## About the Kernel

:::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}
![](images/terminal-shell.png){width="70%" fig-align="center"}
:::
::: {.column .fragment width="50%"}
- The Kernel is the core of the operating system in Unix.
- It takes care of allocating time and memory to programs.
- It does very fundamental root level management.
:::
::::


## About the Shell

:::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}
![](images/terminal-shell.png){width="70%" fig-align="center"}
:::
::: {.column .fragment width="50%"}
- The Shell is the outer layer of the OS
- The shell does 4 simple things:
    + displays a prompt in the terminal window (waiting for commands)
    + reads your command
    + runs the command
    + prints the output, if any, to the Terminal window
:::
::::


## About the Terminal

:::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}
![](images/terminal-shell.png){width="70%" fig-align="center"}
:::
::: {.column .fragment width="50%"}
The __Terminal__ (a.k.a. terminal emulator) is the program provides a text-based environment lets you interact with the shell:

- open windows and tabs
- manage shells
- resize windows
- change colors in windows
- handle copy-paste operations
:::
::::


## Demo (CLI advantages)

Count number of `csv` files

```{r}
#| code-fold: true
#| code-summary: "answer"
#| eval: false
#| echo: true
ls *.csv | wc -l
```

. . .

Count number of `csv` files with `FREESTYLE` in name

```{r}
#| code-fold: true
#| code-summary: "answer"
#| eval: false
#| echo: true
ls *FREESTYLE*.csv | wc -l
```

. . .

Count number of `csv` files with `F-XXX-FREESTYLE` in name

```{r}
#| code-fold: true
#| code-summary: "answer"
#| eval: false
#| echo: true
ls F*FREESTYLE*.csv | wc -l
```

```

```

. . .

```{.markdown filename="Example 3" code-line-numbers="false"}
# no options, one argument

```

. . .

```{.markdown filename="Example 4" code-line-numbers="false"}
# one option, one argument

```

. . .

```{.markdown filename="Example 5" code-line-numbers="false"}
# two options, one argument
ls -la Documents/
```


# Equivalent Commands

R equivalent of Shell commands:

- `getwd()`: like `pwd` in Shell
- `setwd()`: like `cd` in Shell
- `list.files()` and `dir()`: like `ls` in Shell
- `file.copy()`: like `cp` in Shell
- `file.rename()`: like `mv` in Shell
- `file.remove()`: like `rm` in Shell
